channel.title: Ars-Technica on Panz3r News
channel.description: Recent content in Ars-Technica on news.panz3r.dev

item.title: A music video you can play: Indie rock inside the Unity engine
item.description: You’ve seen interactive music before—but an indie mindset changes the game.

item.title: The new Google Pay repeats all the same mistakes of Google Allo
item.description: For P2P users, the new app has fewer features, is less convenient, and has more fees.

item.title: Ars’ plea: Someone make this into a series
item.description: The Ars staff picks the novels we think would make compelling TV adaptations.

item.title: Facebook’s new AI teaches itself to see with less human help
item.description: This new approach eliminates the need for picture labeling.

item.title: Tens of thousands of US organizations hit in ongoing Microsoft Exchange hack
item.description: Multiple hacking groups are exploiting vulnerabilities to backdoor unpatched servers.

item.title: Review: WandaVision sticks the landing with a very Marvel-esque finale
item.description: But the rumored major cameo failed to materialize, despite two post-credit scenes

item.title: A new type of supply-chain attack with serious consequences is flourishing
item.description: New dependency confusion attacks take aim at Microsoft, Amazon, Slack, Lyft, and Zillow.

item.title: We’re living on a planet of ants
item.description: A new book looks at the amazing behaviors of ants and the people who study them.

item.title: Gig companies fear a worker shortage, despite a recession
item.description: Execs feel the strain as pandemic and government aid reduce supply and demand.

item.title: Feds indict John McAfee for cryptocurrency pump-and-dump fraud
item.description: “I am not pumping for my gain,” McAfee wrote. Prosecutors say that wasn’t true.

item.title: China’s and Russia’s spying sprees will take years to unpack
item.description: Full extent of SolarWinds hack, Hafnium’s attack on Exchange Server may never be known.

item.title: Microsoft adds Startup Boost, Sleeping Tabs to Edge build 89
item.description: This new version of Edge brings several notable performance and UX enhancements.

item.title: Visual Studio Code now runs natively on M1 Macs
item.description: App will be available either in universal or architecture-specific binaries.

item.title: Proposed law could force ISPs to stop hiding true size of monthly bills
item.description: “ISPs are notorious for keeping customers in the dark,” bill supporter says.

item.title: Torvalds warns the world: Don’t use the Linux 5.12-rc1 kernel
item.description: Please, please don’t use cowboy kernels in production—especially not this one!

item.title: White House signals coming antitrust push with Tim Wu appointment
item.description: The nod indicates that the new administration isn’t planning to go easy on tech.

item.title: How to beat Paper Mario really fast by… playing Ocarina of Time?
item.description: Hackers use cartridge-swapping method to move memory from one game to another.

item.title: Under intense pressure, WHO skips summary report on coronavirus origin
item.description: The full report, however, is expected the week of March 15.

item.title: The Toyota Highlander hybrid is a big three-row with a buzzy engine
item.description: The continuously variable transmission is not particularly refined.

item.title: Typing my way down the mechanical keyboard rabbit hole with the Drop CTRL
item.description: Customizable, mechanical keyboards can be an expensive niche—this is a nice entry point.

item.title: Rocket Report: SpaceX explains landing failure, more on New Glenn delays
item.description: “The level of detail that we get is remarkable, how good the forecast is.”

item.title: Chairs Technica: We review two new models from Anda Seat
item.description: We liked the Anda Fnatic so much, we’re reviewing two new models as well.

item.title: Meet Maxwell’s gambling demon—smart enough to quit while it’s ahead
item.description: Physicists even demonstrated the basic principle in a nanoscale electronic device.

item.title: US roads got more dangerous in 2020 even though we stayed at home
item.description: Preliminary data puts the death toll at 42,060, with 4.8 million people injured.

item.title: Valve scraps revamped Artifact, dumps free, unfinished “2.0” version on Steam
item.description: Rebuilt game had been in closed beta for one year before Valve pulled the plug today.

item.title: Self-driving startups are becoming an endangered species
item.description: Commercializing self-driving technology is taking longer than many expected.

item.title: Apple clarifies iOS default music app feature, and it’s not what people thought
item.description: The widely reported beta feature was misunderstood.

item.title: Arizona House advances bill targeting Apple, Google mobile app stores
item.description: The Arizona bill has already gotten farther than a similar one in ND did.

item.title: Grab a Nintendo Switch Pro Controller for $10 off today
item.description: Dealmaster also has deals on portable hard drives, our 2020 GOTY, and more.

item.title: Bitflips when PCs try to reach windows.com: What could possibly go wrong?
item.description: Researcher obtains 14 bit- or typo-quatted domains and analyzes their traffic.

item.title: 100Mbps uploads and downloads should be US broadband standard, senators say
item.description: Pandemic showed that “upload speeds far greater than 3Mbps are critical.”

item.title: The Realme GT 5G is the world’s cheapest Snapdragon 888 phone
item.description: $430 for a Snapdragon 888, a 120 Hz OLED display, and speedy 65 W charging.

item.title: SpaceX Starlink factory in Texas will speed up production of Dishy McFlatface
item.description: Austin factory to create systems that improve SpaceX’s high-volume manufacturing.

item.title: Loop Hero review: I’ve somehow gotten hooked on an RPG that plays itself
item.description: Think of it as the ultimate game to play on a second monitor.

item.title: Starship goes up. Starship goes down. But is the program moving forward?
item.description: “One day, the true measure of success will be that Starship flights are commonplace.”

item.title: New Nintendo Switch production to begin in June, will be 4K when docked
item.description: Bloomberg report locks down details about new OLED panel supply chain.

item.title: Researchers build a swimming robot that works in the Mariana Trench
item.description: New muscles and electronics setup were needed for the crushing pressures.

item.title: Facebook lifts ban on US political advertising
item.description: Social media behemoth had been under pressure to rescind post-election moratorium.

item.title: Google claims it will stop tracking individual users for ads
item.description: Google says anonymized, group-based interest tracking will be good enough.

item.title: Comcast hides upload speeds deep inside its infuriating ordering system
item.description: Comcast upload speeds of 3 to 35Mbps are hidden until last page of checkout.

item.title: Parler sues Amazon (again), claims AWS ban sank a billion-dollar valuation
item.description: The lawsuit is dead. Long live the lawsuit.

item.title: This startup has an intriguing concept for EV battery swaps
item.description: The first five stations in the Bay Area will be used by a fleet of electric Ubers.

item.title: SpaceX recycling vehicle for second Starship launch attempt [Updated]
item.description: Musk says he is confident Starship will be ready for a lunar flight in three years.

item.title: EA confirms it isn’t secretly “fixing” FIFA matches
item.description: Lawyers drop “Dynamic Difficulty Adjustment” lawsuit after talking to EA engineers.

item.title: CDC to release guide for life after vaccination—with normalcy still far off
item.description: There are small steps toward normal life, but most activities are still out of bounds.

item.title: All US Apple stores are open for the first time in almost a year
item.description: COVID-19 isn’t gone, but like much of the US, Apple is moving forward.

item.title: Biden pushes EV chargers as six utilities plan a unified network
item.description: Joe Biden has called for 500,000 new EV chargers by 2030.

item.title: Google’s VR dreams are dead: Google Cardboard is no longer for sale
item.description: Google Cardboard is still open source, but Google is done with the project.

item.title: AMD’s RX 6700XT GPU launches March 18 for $479
item.description: At $100 less than RX 6800, it’s being positioned as a 1440p card. If you can buy one.

item.title: Meet this year’s winners of the Dance Your PhD contest
item.description: This year’s contest also featured a special award for best COVID-19-related dance.

item.title: Jane Does v. GirlsDoPorn: How 22 millennial women brought down a porn empire
item.description: GirlsDoPorn deceived vulnerable women to profit off amateur porn—until Jane Does fought back.

item.title: Merck/J&J deal may help US get enough vaccine for all adults by end of May
item.description: Merck will dedicate two facilities to making the newly authorized J�J vaccine.

item.title: Cuttlefish can pass the marshmallow test
item.description: Cuttlefish that were better at self-control also performed better on learning tests.

item.title: Intel hit with $2.2 billion patent judgment
item.description: Patents claim methods of varying voltages and clock frequencies to save power.

item.title: Dish tries to disrupt SpaceX’s Starlink plans as companies fight at FCC
item.description: Dish is trying to “expropriate the 12 GHz band” for itself, SpaceX tells FCC.

item.title: Microsoft issues emergency patches for 4 exploited 0-days in Exchange
item.description: Attacks are limited for now but may ramp up as other hackers learn of them.

item.title: AWS director sues Amazon, alleging systemic racism in corporate office
item.description: Amazon talks up inclusion in public but fails behind the scenes, suit claims.

item.title: Samsung will soon ship Micro LED TVs, but Mini LED still leads the lineup
item.description: Plus, a rundown of the wacky buzzwords you have to know to shop for these TVs.

item.title: “Locked” for 300 years: Virtual unfolding has now revealed this letter’s secrets
item.description: Practice of intricately folding letters to secure them is known as “letterlocking.”

item.title: Today’s best tech deals: Bose headphones, Assassin’s Creed, and more
item.description: Dealmaster also has portable Bluetooth speakers, board games, and the iPad Air.

item.title: Rookie coding mistake prior to Gab hack came from site’s CTO
item.description: Site executive introduces, then removes, insecure code, then hides the evidence.

item.title: Epic continues its studio-acquisition spree, buys Fall Guys devs
item.description: Free-to-play? Steam changes? “Nothing to announce right now!”

item.title: Google-free /e/ OS is now selling preloaded phones in the US, starting at $380
item.description: If DIY flashing isn’t your thing, refurbished Samsung devices are now available.
